revision.comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/143.167.103.189|143.167.103.189]]: Copyright issue re https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/news/nr/university-sheffield-number-one-for-library-information-management-1.767263. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=July 2014}} The '''Information School''' or '''iSchool''' of the [[University of Sheffield]], in [[Sheffield]], [[South Yorkshire]], [[England]], was founded in 1963 as the University's '''Postgraduate School of Librarianship''' and became in 2010 the first UK [[iSchool]]. Other names were the '''Postgraduate School of Librarianship and Information Science''' ('''PGSLIS''', 1967-81) and '''Department of Information Studies''' (1981-2011).<ref>{{cite web|title=iSchool Timeline|url=http://www.shef.ac.uk/is/about/history.html|work=University of Sheffield: Information School|accessdate=8 October 2011}}</ref> {{As of|2015}}, it employs 28 academic staff, 12 administrative/support staff, 7 affiliated research staff, and has about 50 research students. The current head of school is Professor Peter Bath.
The department opened in 1964 as a library school, becoming only the second university-based department in the UK.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/016555158901500402 |last=Saunders |first=W. |year=1989|title=The University of Sheffield Department of Information Studies|journal=Journal of Information Science|volume=15 |issue=4-5| pages = 193–202}}</ref> Since then, like many [[information science]] departments it has grown to encompass teaching and research in [[cheminformatics]], educational informatics, [[health informatics]], [[information retrieval]], [[information systems]], knowledge and information management, as well as libraries and information society. Such is the status of the school, that it has twice been honoured with a special issue of the ''[[Journal of Information Science]]'' devoted entirely to the department, its staff and its research outputs.<ref>{{cite journal |year=1989 | journal=Journal of Information Science|volume=15 |issue=4-5|url=http://jis.sagepub.com/content/vol15/issue4-5/|title=The University of Sheffield Department of Information Studies}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |year=2003|title=Special Issue, 40 years of the Department of Information Studies, University of Sheffield|journal=Journal of Information Science|volume=29 |issue=4|url=http://jis.sagepub.com/content/vol29/issue4/}}</ref>
==Research achievements== The school has ranked highest or joint highest in its subject rating in every [[Research Assessment Exercise]] since the running of the first exercise in 1986. In this UK-government sponsored assessment of research outputs, no other department in its subject field (or its [[University of Sheffield|University]]) achieved this consistency; few departments of any subject area in UK universities managed such a high level of continuous research output (see the following links to the 1992,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rae.ac.uk/1992/c26_92t64.html |title=UFC 26/92 - RAE92: The Outcome Table 64 |publisher=Rae.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}}</ref> 1996,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rae.ac.uk/1996/1_96/t61.html |title=1996 RAE - Unit of Assessment: 61 |publisher=Rae.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}}</ref> 2001<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rae.ac.uk/2001/results/byuoa/uoa61.htm |title=Results : 2001 Research Assessment Exercise : Unit of Assessment : 61 Library and Information Management |publisher=Rae.ac.uk |accessdate=2015-05-16}}</ref> RAE results). In 2008, rankings of departments was left to news organizations; the [[Times Higher Education]] placed Sheffield at No. 1 again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/Journals/THE/THE/18_December_2008/attachments/RAE_2008_THE_RESULTS.pdf |format=PDF |title=Times Higher Education Table of Excellence |publisher=Timeshighereducation.co.uk |accessdate=2015-05-16}}</ref>
In 2008, an analysis of citations showed four of the ten most cited UK information studies academics were working in the Sheffield department.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/asi.20771 |url=http://eprints.whiterose.ac.uk/4579/ |last=Sanderson |first=M. | year=2008 | title=Revisiting h measured on UK LIS and IR academics| journal=Journal of the American Society for Information Science and Technology (JASIST) |volume=59 |issue=7| pages=1184–1190}}</ref> It is also the first UK-based (and 2nd European) department to be become an [[i-school|iSchool]].
==Notable staff, past and present== * Micheline Beaulieu - Chair of the Computing and Informatics Panel of the [[European Research Council]] (2008-2011) * [[Sheila Corrall]] - first President of [[Chartered Institute of Library and Information Professionals]] (CILIP), 2002-3:. * [[Michael Lynch (researcher)|Michael Lynch]], researcher * [[W. L. Saunders]], Director of the Postgraduate School of Librarianship, Sheffield * Bob Usherwood - President of the Library Association, 1998; fellow of the [[Royal Society of Arts]]. * [[Steve Whittaker]] - inducted into the [[SIGCHI]] academy in 2008. * Paul Clough<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sheffield.ac.uk/is/staff/clough|title=Prof Paul Clough|website=Information School|publisher=University of Sheffield|access-date=2 February 2017}}</ref> - Head of Information Retrieval Research Group * [[Peter Willett]] - leading researcher in [[cheminformatics]]. * [[Thomas D. Wilson|Tom Wilson]] - recipient of the 2009 ASIS&T SIG USE award for "''outstanding contributions to information behavior''"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asis.org/SIG/SIGUSE/awards.php|title=SIG USE : Awards|work=Asis.org|accessdate=2015-05-16}}</ref> and [[Association for Information Science and Technology]] (ASIS&T) Award of Merit, 2017.
==Notable alumni== * [[Michael Buckland]] - Emeritus Professor at the University of California--Berkeley School of Information and Co-Director of the Electronic Cultural Atlas Initiative * [[John McTernan]] - Director of Political Operations at [[10 Downing Street]] under [[Tony Blair]]. * [[Alasdair Paterson]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scottishpoetrylibrary.org.uk/poetry/poets/alasdair-paterson|title=Alasdair Paterson|website=Scottish Poetry Library|access-date=2 February 2017}}</ref> - poet, winner of the 1975 [[Eric Gregory Award]] for poetry.
==References== <references/>
==Further reading== *Saunders, W. L., ed. ''University and Research Library Studies: some contributions from the University of Sheffield Post-graduate School of Librarianship and Information Science''. Oxford: Pergamon Press, 1968 *{{cite journal|date=2014|last1=Benson|first1=Melanie T.|last2= Willett|first2= Peter||title=The Information School at the University of Sheffield, 1963-2013|work=[[Journal of Documentation]]|volume= 70|pages=1141–1158|authorlink2=Peter Willett}}
==External links== * [http://www.shef.ac.uk/is/ University of Sheffield Information School home page]
[[Category:University of Sheffield]] [[Category:Information schools]] [[Category:Library science education]]

{{Infobox person | name = Zubin Damania | image = Zdoggmd.png | caption = Damania Speaking at TEDMED 2013 | image_size = 200px | birth_place = [[New Jersey]], United States | occupation = [[hospitalist]], Internet celebrity [[ZDoggMD]] | nationality = [[United States|American]] | education = [[UC Berkeley]] (1994)
[[UCSF]] Medical School (1999) [[Doctor of Medicine|MD]] | website = {{URL|http://www.zdoggmd.com}} | footnotes = | residence = [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], Nevada, United States }} '''Zubin Damania''' is the founder of [[Turntable Health]], a direct primary care clinic in [[Downtown Las Vegas]] that was funded by [[Zappos]] CEO [[Tony Hsieh]]. Before moving to Las Vegas, Damania was a practicing [[hospitalist]] (internal medicine physician specializing in patients admitted to the hospital) at [[Stanford University]] for 10 years. He also has been writing and performing comedic raps as [[ZDoggMD]], an [[internet celebrity]] known for his music videos, parodies, and comedy sketches about medical issues as well as systemic issues with healthcare.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/11/08/speaking-of-rhymes-and-medicine/ |title=Speaking Of… Rhymes and Medicine with ZDoggMD (TCTV) |publisher=TechCrunch |date=2010-11-08 |accessdate=2014-03-10}} ==Early life and education== Damania grew up in [[Clovis, California]], with his parents, both [[Parsi]] doctors who immigrated from [[India]], and two siblings.{{cite web|author= |url=http://downtownproject.com/2012/the-doctor-is-in-the-hizzouse/ |title=The Doctor is in the Hizzouse |publisher=Downtown Project |date=2012-05-03 |accessdate=2014-03-10}} He attended [[Clovis West High School]] before going on to receive an undergraduate degree at [[UC Berkeley]], where he studied music and molecular biology. While there he completed a research thesis in a genetics lab on integrin-mediated cell-cell adhesion pathways in the ''[[Drosophila melanogaster]]'' model with [[James Fristrom]].{{cite web|url=http://www.genetics.org/content/146/1/275 |title=Autosomal Mutations Affecting Adhesion Between Wing Surfaces in Drosophila melanogaster |publisher=Genetics.org |date=1997-05-01 |accessdate=2014-03-10}} Damania attended medical school at [[UCSF]] and graduated in 1999. His time in school was marked by a series of pursuits that combined comedy and medicine: he streamed medical comedy routines for a startup called Medschool.com, and performed medical based standup routines for drug companies, hospitals and other medical organizations. He also gave the commencement speech at UCSF at his graduation, which has had tens of thousands of views on YouTube, and made NPR's list of top commencement speeches of all time.{{cite web|url=http://apps.npr.org/commencement/speech/zubin-damania-university-of-california-san-francisco-1999/|title=Zubin Damania, 1999|publisher=|accessdate=12 September 2016}} One of two graduating students chosen to speak at the commencement ceremony he delivered a satirical speech to an audience that included [[Nobel Prize]] winner [[J. Michael Bishop]], and that has since garnered tens of thousands of views on [[YouTube]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mgnHH7Iz37c |title=Funny Graduation Speech | UCSF Med School | ZDoggMD.com |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-04-21 |accessdate=2014-03-10}} ==Career== After completing his residency at Stanford University, Damania stayed on at Palo Alto Medical Foundation for ten years as a hospitalist, where he received the Russell Lee Award for Clinical Teaching while simultaneously maintaining a side hobby performing stand-up comedy for medical audiences worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.tedmed.com/speakers/show?id=34751 |title=Speaker: Zubin Damania |publisher=TEDMED |date= |accessdate=2014-03-10}} Disheartened by the traditional fee for service model on which the American medical system is based, Damania became increasingly frustrated with his work. With the encouragement of Tony Hsieh, the CEO of Zappos.com, Damania began writing, performing and filming musical parodies about the frustrations of work as a doctor, posting them on YouTube to immediate success. He developed a persona called [[ZDoggMD]] fashioned as a [[Gangsta rap|gangsta]] rapper who was upset about popular misconceptions of healthcare in the US. Damania gave a presentation called "Are Zombie Doctors Taking Over America?" at [[TEDMED]] 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.tedmed.com/talks/show?id=34752 |title=Talk Details - Are zombie doctors taking over America? |publisher=TEDMED |date= |accessdate=2014-03-10}} In it he outlines the lingering problems of the US healthcare system and how he has re-conceived it at Turntable Health into a patient-centered organization dedicated to preventative care. His speech was called one of the best of the conference.{{cite web|last=Baum |first=Stephanie |url=http://medcitynews.com/2013/04/get-a-peek-at-6-of-the-best-tedmed-2013-talks-video/ |title=Get a peek at the 6 best TEDMED 2013 talks (video) |publisher=Medcitynews.com |date=2013-04-19 |accessdate=2014-03-10}} [[US News and World Report]] called his critique of American healthcare "scalpel-sharp" and "at once discomfiting and comic".{{cite web|author=Megan Johnson, Steve Sternberg |url=http://health.usnews.com/health-news/blogs/second-opinion/2013/04/22/tedmed-zdoggmd-and-the-state-of-healthcare |title=TEDMED, ZDoggMD and the State of Healthcare - US News |publisher=Health.usnews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-10}} Since beginning work on the clinic, Damania has been named one of the "top 14 people to watch in 2014"{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/news/2014/jan/09/dr-zubin-damania-ceo-and-founder-turntable-health/ |title=Dr. Zubin Damania, CEO and Founder of Turntable Health |publisher=Las Vegas Weekly |date=2014-01-09 |accessdate=2014-03-10}} by ''[[Las Vegas Weekly]]'', and has been profiled in ''[[The Atlantic Monthly]]'',{{cite web|last=Rosenfeld |first=Paul |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/10/the-doctor-rapper-and-ceo-who-intend-to-fix-healthcare/280438/ |title=The Doctor-Rapper and CEO Who Intend to Fix Healthcare - Aimee Swartz |publisher=The Atlantic |date=2013-10-10 |accessdate=2014-03-10}} [[Xconomy]],{{cite web|url=http://www.xconomy.com/boston/2014/01/14/welcome-to-zappos-style-health-innovation/ |title=Welcome to Zappos-Style Health Innovation |publisher=Xconomy |date=2014-01-14 |accessdate=2014-03-10}} ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'', [[Venture Beat]], [[Gizmodo]], [[MSNBC]] and [[USA Today]].{{cite web|url=http://www.zdoggmd.com/about-z/ |title=Medical Humor | Funny Videos |publisher=ZDoggMD |date= |accessdate=2014-03-10}} Turntable Health was also named "by far the most exciting healthcare startup" and "revolutionary" by The Next Web.{{cite web|last=Gerber |first=Scott |url=https://thenextweb.com/entrepreneur/2014/01/26/8-ways-startups-revolutionizing-health-care/#!vYs5H |title=8 Ways Startups Are Changing the Healthcare Industry |publisher=Thenextweb.com |date=2014-01-26 |accessdate=2014-03-10}} ==ZDoggMD== {{Infobox person | name = ZDoggMD (character) | image = ZDoggMD.jpg | birth_name = | nationality = American | known_for = Viral videos | website = {{URL|www.zdoggmd.com}} }}'''ZDoggMD''' is an alias of Damania, and under the name he makes music videos, parodies, and comedy sketches about contemporary medical issues and working in the medical field."Speaking Of…Rhymes and Medicine with ZDoggMD (TCTV)," by [[Cyan Banister]], TechCrunch, November 8, 2010, https://techcrunch.com/2010/11/08/speaking-of-rhymes-and-medicine/ === Current endeavors === ZdoggMD has been featured or interviewed in several medical-based, and other types of well-known publications including [[The Atlantic Monthly]],[https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/10/the-doctor-rapper-and-ceo-who-intend-to-fix-healthcare/280438/ The Doctor-Rapper and CEO Who Intend to Fix Healthcare] [[TechCrunch]], [[Radio Rounds]],"605: Slightly Funnier Than Placebo," Radio Rounds, October 9, 2011, http://www.radiorounds.org/episode-guide/slightly-funnier-than-placebo/ [[The Guardian]],"Immunize," GRRLSCIENTIST, http://www.guardian.co.uk/science/punctuated-equilibrium/2011/mar/07/1?CMP=twt_fd [[Mental floss]], ReachMD,[http://www.reachmd.com/xmsegment.aspx?sid=5955 ReachMD - Program - Second Opinion Goes Back to Med School] [[ScienceBlogs]], ACP Hospitalist, and Today's Hospitalist,"Hospital medicine's sickest flow: ZDoggMD is in the house!," Today's Hospitalist, November 2010 issue, http://www.todayshospitalist.com/index.php?b=articles_read&cnt=1119 among others. His website won the 2010 Best New Medical Weblog at the 2010 Medical Weblog Awards sponsored by [[Epocrates]] and [[Lenovo]]."2010 Medical Weblog Awards Sponsored by Epocrates and Lenovo: Meet the Winners!," by Gene Ostrovsky, medGadget, Feb 16, 2011, http://medgadget.com/2011/02/2010_medical_weblog_awards_sponsored_by_epocrates_and_lenovo_meet_the_winners.html His videos feature a rotating cast of several characters, also practicing doctors, including, most often, Dr. Harry, a pediatrician, and Doc Quixote, Dr. Diego and others. He often collaborates musically with Southern California DJ and Producer samix, who produced the album Midriff Music by [[Josh Martinez]] which won the category "Best Rap Recording" award at the 2005 [[Western Canadian Music Awards]]. He is also currently collaborating with Devin Moore, a composer, bassist in the band “Rabbit!” and member of Downtown Project’s music development team in Las Vegas.[http://www.knoxville.com/news/2011/aug/11/knoxville-music-rabbit-ashton-allen-devon-moore/] ZdoggMD's work has been called "entertainment that might save your life"{{fact|date=May 2017}}, he has been labeled "the jolliest doctor on the West Coast", and "a genuine doctor who uses YouTube as a creativity outlet to teach people about things like safe sex, delivering bad news, stayin' healthy on vacation and hemorrhoids." His videos cover topics such as ulcers, testicular exams, Caribbean medical schools, stool transplants, overworked doctors, the role of hospitalists in medicine versus other specialists, vaccine controversies, healthcare in the US, CPR, television doctors, and being on call during the holidays. ==Turntable Health== In 2012 Tony Hsieh invited Damania to visit Las Vegas, where Hsieh was in the process of investing $350 million of his own money in a project he hoped would revitalize Downtown Las Vegas ([[The Downtown Project]]). He was successful in convincing Damania to quit his job as Physician at Stanford and move his family to Nevada. Hsieh tasked Damania with "fixing Healthcare in Vegas".{{cite web|last=Schoenmann |first=Joe |url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2013/jan/12/joe-downtown-new--downtown-doctor-sets-out-desmyst/ |title=Joe Downtown: New-to-downtown doctor sets out to demystify medicine - Las Vegas Sun News |publisher=Lasvegassun.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-10}} Once in Las Vegas, Damania continued to produce videos both as ZDoggMD and himself while working on opening Turntable Health. While conceiving of the idea for Turntable Health, Damania met Rushika Fernandopulle, co-founder and CEO of a Boston-based startup called Iora Health, who had become well known for his vision to rebuild healthcare by removing fee-for-service episodic payments from primary care, focusing on prevention, and using a membership model. The two forged a partnership. Turntable Health, a direct primary care clinic in Downtown Las Vegas, was the result of their collaboration. It was based on a patient focused, preventative model that subscribers could either pay a monthly fee for, or have as part of their coverage in some cases.{{cite web|last=Rake |first=Launce |url=http://lasvegascitylife.com/blog/town/downtown-clinic-promises-new-model-health-care.html |title=Downtown Clinic Promises "New Model" Of Health Care |publisher=Las Vegas CityLife |date= |accessdate=2014-03-10}} The clinic opened in December, 2013, and was an integral part of Hsieh’s Downtown Project of revitalizing Las Vegas and re-visualizing urban spaces. Turntable Health shut down as of January 31, 2017. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.turntablehealth.com Turntable Health] * [http://www.zdoggmd.com ZDoggMD Official] * {{YouTube|u=ZDoggMD|{{PAGENAMEBASE}}}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Damania, Zubin}} [[Category:Internet memes]] [[Category:Internet celebrities]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley alumni]] [[Category:Viral videos]] [[Category:YouTube videos]] [[Category:People from the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Healthcare quality]] [[Category:American health care businesspeople]] [[Category:Medical educators]] [[Category:American health care chief executives]] [[Category:American people of Parsi descent]] [[Category:Parsi people]] [[Category:21st-century American physicians]]
